Few years ago Facebook used to restrict user signups with .edu emails only. Why did they remove that restriction and what were the pros & cons of doing so?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Facebook was growing in the colleges rapidly and had already met their old goal of connecting all students in all colleges. They now had a new mission, "To give people the power to share and make the world more open and connected.” In order to grow rapidly and towards that mission, they opened up user signups for everyone not just .edu emails.
Pros: Rapid growth
Cons: Resource needs (network, servers, funding), churn from early users that didn't feel they belonged to FB anymore

What was the interview question?: Design a travel app for Google
What is the success metrics for FB stories?
If you are the PM for FB Shops and you see the items sold per week is up but the # of messages on marketplace is down, how would you evaluate this tradeoff?
Comments (e.g. your approach): The question is about 2 FB products:  FB Shops and FB Marketplace.  That wasn't clear to me when I answered the question.    IN that case, I think it's important to first diagnose what caused the drop in Marketplace messages before jumping into the trade off.  If after, all the possible root causes eliminated and you are convinced that it is in fact caused by a new feature in Shops, then I would want to understand if the drop in messages is impacting the success of Marketplace, (again, for marketplace, your success metric is # of items sold).  If the drop in messages is correlated with drop in # of items sold in Marketplace,  then you are trading off items being sold in Marketplace with items being sold in Shops. With the introduction of Shops feature,  it's reasonable to assume that people who used to sell in Marketplace are now opening shops in Shops.   It would then make sense to look at the total of Marketplace and Shops items sold and make sure it's growing. So rather than looking at each, you're making sure the total is growing at a healthy rate.

Comments (e.g. your approach): Asked some clarifying questions. Most of the interviewers responses to my questions were make some assumptions and go with it. She gave me context on Oculus when I asked but didn't expect me Started high-level talking about Facebook's mission and why a product like this would even be relevant/why FB would want to do this. Broke down what "education" actually means and what I was going to focus on. Highlighted some potential users. Prioritized one group. Highlighted their specific needs. Ideated. Discussed Tradeoffs. Remember to speak clearly and concisely, and take breaks!

Pick an object near you. What attributes do you consider as important for this product. How to improve it?
Comments (e.g. your approach): I've picked a chair. I considered the purpose of the chair (for work, to eat in a dinning table, etc) and then for each different aspects such as ergonomic, comfort, adjustable to different people sizes and heights, materials, without without arms... I received a question during my answer to focus in baby chairs. Then I changed my analysis to baby safety (no swelling parts of the chair) and functionalities to parents to feed them for instance. In terms of improvements, I commented on electronics that help measure whether you are sitting right and that could adjust to people automatically...

What was the interview question?: How would you improve google maps? Consider many solutions to the problem.
Comments (e.g. your approach): I started that I used google maps to find restaurants / museums, and but then I had not necessarily an easy link to place an order or buy an entrance ticket. Then we discussed solutions such as a partnership with grub-hub or building an auxiliary system for that and then the conversation went to liabilities of providing duch additonal service and also technological barriers such as linking a mobile app to a secondary app (like facebook opening messenger).

What was the interview question?: Tell me about a technological trend is going on and what Google could do to follow this trend and provide a product related to this trend?
Comments (e.g. your approach): I told some (not much) about IOT (Intenet of Things) and that it would be great to know where public parking spots are there in a city and that normally we would need to install a bunch of sensors all over the city. Then the interviewer challenged me to find a way to solve the problem without sensors. My answer was obtaining secondary data on private parking to meausre statistically the probability of public spaces and also using people in google maps to report when they are parking or leaving a parking space. Then we discussed how to stimulate people providing such information (such as discount on parking fees)

What was the interview question?: Pick an app that you like to listen to music/podcasts. What this app's goal, what it does well, what can be improved? Of improvements, which one to prioritize to increase engagement.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Picked Apple Podcasts.
Goal as provide people ability to consume any information they want in an easy way.
What they do well: content, app is easy to use, you can download podcasts fast even when not on wi-fi (good compression?)
What to improve: prediction algorithm, get more exclusive content, cover more demographics
Decided that algorithm will increase engagement as the other two will be more for attracting new customers which is not the goal.

1. How do you manage scope when unexpected hurdles pop up [close to a deadline]?
2. How do you prioritize?
3. How do you lead engineers, designers, etc.?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
1. Ensure expectations around scope & timeline are aligned w/ leadership --> is cutting scope possible? Balancing trade-offs (needed vs. nice-to-have's)
2. Consider: What is the benefit to the end user? How the end user will interact w/ the technology? Lowest hanging fruits (that can be tackled w/ tweaking existing code/design)? Only attend to user going astray when it's a pattern! Newly discovered req.’s can be reduced by thinking out & creating exceptions, edge-cases, trade-offs, etc.
3. Ensuring objectives & motivations are aligned --> do so by facilitating organized yet free-flowing communication & keeping them updated on any relevant changes & finding opportunities for buy-in when possible (e.g. participating in user interview or testing when helpful) --> provided my experience working w/ engineers & how I achieved that in my "product spec"

You were recently hired as a Product Manager for an education portal. It's Website that has courses that people can take, for example, Python programming. Your product is close to launching; what metrics are you interested in tracking and preparing for and why?
Several follow up questions: Course launches, 2-weeks in and conversions are at 10%. What do you do? Let’s say 10K go to the page but only 100 add to cart and only 10 convert; what is your approach?
Comments (e.g. your approach): Clarify the situation, ask for details on the product, briefly talk about users and their needs/pain points. List some metrics, pick one, defend why the metric was chosen. Debug followup questions about poor conversion ratios.

What was the interview question?: You are the PM for FB News. What success metric would you track and why?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
1) Clarified the Product (what FB News is/does). 2) Spoke to where the product currently is in its lifecycle. 3) Ran through what the typical user journey looks like. 4) As the product is mature, identified Retention as the key metric (Engagement as a top L1 metric). 5) Drilled into key topline metrics such as DAU, WAU, DAU/WAU ratio, and Time Spent Per User. 6) Talked about key user metrics such as Likes, Shares, Comments and Hides (to help refine algo), 7) Reiterated the key success metric and the other Top metrics.
Interviewer seemed very happy with that framework and how I spoke to it.

What was the interview question?:
1) What's your favorite Google product and how would you improve it?
2) You are the PM for a product and you just launched the pilot. There is a competing priority on a new feature request and a bug that was found post launch. How will you decide which one to pick?
3) How would you create a playlist for a user after they listen to a single song?
How do you prioritize given a limited bandwidth of resources?
Comments (e.g. your approach): I drew on my experiences from managing 6 concurrent trials in clinical research, and how I would prioritize based on patient issues, and upcoming study milestone deadlines. I went into detail on how I would work with cross-functional teams involved in deadlines to make sure they had the resources and time needed to accomplish their part.

Comments (e.g. your approach):
I divided it into 3 parts
1. Approach - Where we should launch and why we should launch over there. What should be the plan for next phases
2. Solution - How will be the product offering? Will it be a subscription model, use basis offering or a mix of both
3. Finally what metric we will look at from product standpoint and from business standpoint

Comments (e.g. your approach): I think this is similar to a "what's your favorite product and why" question but they want to get around the framework. My approach was to start with the goal or jtbd for the product and then highlight where it breaks down. The interesting piece of this is you also need to highlight why it's still successful. I pointed to products that have strong distribution or strong moats (e.g. iCal b/c it's the default on all Apple products)

What was the interview question?: You've been hired by a group of companies in the air travel space. How would you improve the public perception of air travel given $10M and 1 year?
Comments (e.g. your approach): This feels like a "improve this product" in disguise, so I followed a similar framework. Starting with who are the companies hiring me and their motivations. I set a goal to improve engagement which will likely have positive downstream effects for the airlines (e.g. monetization).  Then I wanted to think about the customer segments that we could target to improve engagement (e.g. leisure vs. business travelers). Prioritized a customer segment and then went deeper on pain points for that group (e.g. costs, delays, service). From there listed a few solutions and prioritized those. Assigned dollar values to add up to $10M budget.

How did you handle a situation as Product operations manager when 2 of your stakeholders wanted to prioritize their own request.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Framework used: Think of big picture -what problem we are solving, what is the objective of the product / project. Analyze what impact both stakeholder's requests are causing on the overall objective of program / project (in line the goals? short term - ling term milestones?). Next review the prioritization criteria ? Do we have one, if no then build one and share the analysis with both stakeholders showing the impact it will create on milestones and seek their votes and align. 

Followed by real life example from project.

Shopify powers online and offline commerce for 1 Million+ merchants across the world. We recently determined that 60% of visitors across all Shopify-powered online stores view the store's return policy page. We think this is because the ease of returning an item is part of a customer’s purchasing decision (“should I buy this or not?”).

However, merchants receive no support from Shopify in providing a good returns experience for their customers other than:
providing a simple default returns policy,
supporting a returns policy page in most themes, and 
the capability for a merchant to send money back to a customer

Our hypothesis is that better support for friendly returns processes will ultimately make our merchants more successful. Assuming you have 6 months and a fully staffed team, how would you go about tackling this problem?
Comments (e.g. your approach): Defined the problem, why should shopify solve it, pain points, solution and north start metric

In my product sense interview, I was asked 2 questions. This was first one where I was given 10 minutes. For Facebook Newsfeed, we are evaluating a recommendation engine that shows most recent content first as opposed to the default algorithm that shows most relevant content to users. How would people react to the 2 different recommendation algorithms.
Comments (e.g. your approach): This question really threw me off as it was not a classic product design question asked in the product sense interviews. I clarified if the interviewer wanted to look at tradeoff metrics to which he said no. I talked about different user types and how they would react (positively and negatively) to this algorithm with respect to engagement for consumers and content producers.

What was the interview question?: In my product sense interview, I was asked 2 questions. This was second one where I was given 25-30 minutes. Meta Workplace is a B2B product that companies pay for and it has no advertising. It has newsfeed, messaging, groups as the main features. Facebook is considering whether we should introduce a calendar feature for Workplace. Should FB launch a calendar feature or not ?
Comments (e.g. your approach): This question really threw me off as it was not a classic product design question asked in the product sense interviews. The curveball part was that the product feature was already given to me. I interpreted the question as 'Design a Calendar application for Workplace' and did the dance (users, pain points). Before I reached the solutions point, I had 5 minutes left in the interview, and the interviewer reminded me the question is "should FB build this product or not". None of my preparation or training helped me answer this question because product sense is not supposed to be general product strategy interview. I didn't get the offer but the recruiter told me later on that I lacked structure in my interviews but did well with users and metrics etc.

What was the interview question?: What goals would you set for Reels recommendation engine.
Comments (e.g. your approach): I clarified that this is Reels for FB and not Instagram. I did the regular dance of user types, metric categories, prioritization, goal setting logic etc. Interviewer probed me why I did not pick a complex metric e.g. average reels viewed to which I responded that it was a combination of 3 metrics -  viewer adoption, viewer engagement and producer engagement, but eventually agreed with him that if I had to pick 1 metric that is not minimum viewer engagement, then avg reels viewed will be a better choice since it represents engagement across friends, influencers, large companies, entertainers etc.

What was the interview question?: 2.	You area a PM at Uber , Uber is looking at extending product line in bUS service , weather BUS service is a good idea or not how would be strategize
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Set a business objective: You should start by making sure you understand the question properly and by defining a specific strategic objective with your interviewer
Generate solutions: Once you know what the objective is, it’s time to generate a structured list of solutions to solve the strategic problem you face
Discuss solutions: After generating solutions, a discussion will naturally follow with your interviewer around the trade-offs and priorities of different solutions
Conclude: Finally, you should conclude the discussion by making a recommendation and answering the initial question you were asked

Imagine you are the product manager at meta. How would you design a product for hyperlocal experiences?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
- Clarified on definition of hyperlocal - Defined it as a community of people in a 2-3 km radius and assumed geography as India
- Talked about different type of community needs in a hyperlocal space - public services, local grocery delivery, food delivery, parcel delivery, making new friends for shared interests like playing badminton (Prioritised public services since it was underserved with respect to things like sewage cleaning, electricity outage in an area, community traffic problems, water logging in roads which are unique to India) 
- Then defined the high level goal (based on reframing the problem) - Connect people to things that matter most in their nearby community 
- Talked about user segments (working professionals, homemakers, students, old age/retired people) and picked one (busy working professionals) which is a good TAM and need for solving the problem
- Talked about pain points of working professionals with respect to pubic services ( not sure who is the right person to contact ,  unsure if online public portals are helpful,  uncertainty on promise from public servants, unable to plan things around public service disruption) 
- Solution - helping working professionals discover people who are facing similar problems in their community,  connect over a virtual online event in facebook, get into a private virtual room with people who have expressed interest on solving this and get the collective thoughts into a plan for action like calling someone (or) putting an online petition etc. and  finally share what worked what didn't work for the benefit of the larger public and finally helping the community to pin these thoughts (or) into a saved section of Q&A

You are a PM in Meta, joined a team of engineers who have created a product FB trees. As a first PM in the team, define the goals and success metrics for FB Trees (Hypothetical product) - Read the desc for more details on FB Trees.
Follow up: PM from another team FB Books comes up and asks to chop trees to make books as his goal is to enable ppl to get access to more and more physical books. What would you do.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
FB Trees is a product for the physical world, that helps in repopulating trees in forests. Assume this is live in Brazil for two years and 100,000 trees/month are being planted. 
Clarifying question: Does FB plant these trees or does it enable ppl to plant trees - Ans. enables ppl to plant trees, lets say that a user enters zip code and the app tells nearby forests and later you can publish the successful planting of trees. 
My approach was to define a broad product goal and users (ppl who plant and post about it, ppl who view those posts), defined a user journey, defined metrics and counter metrics for both and came up with a success metric. 
 Considered engagement metric as a NS for Brazil and adoption metric as a NS for all other countries. 
for the follow up: weighed the pros and cons of planting and chopping trees and traded off.

What was the interview question?: If you are PM at Meta and we are launching a Bookmark feature for Facebook app Newsfeed  tell me why we should launch this product and identify goals and key metrics for this product. Tradeoff question after 4 weeks of launch time spent increases on Newsfeed but overall engagement decreases what will you do?
Comments (e.g. your approach): Interviewer lead the discussion throughout - (actually there was one more interviewer she was shadowing or training the other interviewer) first he asked why you want to build this product kind of what is the motivation - So I asked clarifying question to understand the product and i was informed it could be for any content Reels/post/videos, I have asked where this feature will appear and clarified are do you want me to think more from creator side or viewer side - Interviewer said viewer side - identified 3 situation why Facebook wants to build this Bookmark/Save for later feature. Talked about Meta's mission and why this feature will make sense/motivation to build. Created high level Goal for this feature. Interviewer asked directly for metrics but i asked him if i can Identify User segments and user journey so it can help me to define metrics and he was ok and very friendly. Came up with key metrics and asked if he wants me to think in any other direction and interviewer pointed me to also think about negative scenarios for this product. Came up with couple more metrics. Interviewer asked me for a counter metric - I asked him i can define NSM and he was ok. I defined North star metric and then came up with counter metric. For Tradeoff question asked a lot of follow up question to make sure it is due to the launch of new product Bookmark only and there is no other experiment running or no changes to newsfeed and other metrics are not affected also metrics were stable before launch. Came up with hypothesis it is due to launch of new product only. But wanted to run A/.B test to confirm. Defined control and variant and created a test with metrics to measure. Define impact and what we can do to launch or not.

What was the interview question?: How will you launch Youtube in a new country which doesn't have any such/similar  products
Comments (e.g. your approach):
1. Clarifications:
-  on what my role is in the launch (mostly to understand where to should I focus on - either on Market analysis before the launch / or focus on the launch strategy itself)
- Any specific constraints to be aware of (Infrastructure, regulatory concerns, Low internet bandwidth etc.,)
2. Overall structure
 - Decide what category I am going to choose based on the market research, split the launch into 3 phases - Pre-launch, launch and post launch.
3. Pre-launch: Most preparatory work for launch - how to target the customer segment, what device they use, should I partner with any network operator, Hiring video content creators for the category , Define success for launchetc.,
4. Launch: Actually launch the app with limited features, recommending all the new local content, Promoting content creation with rewards etc.,
5. Post-launch: Measure success metrics and compare with definition, document challenges faced, decide go / no-go / further experiment.

What was the interview question?: How do you prioritize a roadmap
What are your strengths as a PM

Company: Navi (fintech startup in India founded by ex Flipkart)
What was the interview question?: Tool to improve the life of a PM
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Automating the life of a PM

Scope Definition
Choice of PM: Senior PMs since they have to manage roadmap, resourcing tradeoffs & also build products & drive GTM. Largest TAM segment.
Objective: If this tool is successful, PMs should be able to a) deliver more projects on time & b) have the entire team aligned on the problem, solution & metrics which should lead to better quality products with increased productivity. 
Success Metrics & Outcomes:
Input metrics: a) reduction in PRD delays, Execution delays, GTM delays b) reduced escalations on alignment misses leading leading to 
Output metrics: improved biz outcomes and more products launched successfully/quarter


User Journey, Existing Solutions & Unmet Needs

Creation & Closure of Action Items 

Tracking of action items is a key user requirement which is reflected in identifying priority business problems at the roadmap stage. It is also required when putting together the business problem & identifying product solves. Unmet needs are on the following lines.

Inconvenience in creating action items which are not focused on product building:
There exist tools like Asana & Trello to track action items but they are fairly inconvenient to set up. A roadmap of 7-8 projects with 8-10 action items in each would require the user to do at least 60-80 clicks on the drag & drop UI which is far more inconvenient than setting up a Google sheet. Unfortunately, none of these task management tools allow consumption from Sheets/Excel. 
Additionally, product focused roadmap & PRD action item tracking can be standardized into frameworks to create convenience for PMs to start tracking but is missing right now. Miro has taken a shot at creating product focused templates while storyboarding but no such solutions exist for action item tracking.
Reminders & Escalations  - No task management tool currently supports reminders & escalations across channels like email & slack on priority threads.

Roadmap Creation, Consumption & Tradeoffs
The list of initiatives needs to be prioritised with tradeoffs on resourcing vs impact and needs to be aligned with product & biz leadership. This also needs to be consumed by engineering.
Creating tradeoffs & options is inconvenient: While JIRA allows for creating epics & stories, it does not solve for creating a set of initiatives tagged to metrics so that the net view can be presented to leadership with multiple options/tradeoffs. Creating multiple views & tradeoffs has to be done on Google sheets.
Inconvenient to revisit during PRD stage: This is usually on some Google sheet that is rarely referenced except for execution reviews with leadership. Not having this easily accessible leads to forgotten scope, scope bloat & inability to manage feedback.
Building mental models for thinking & presentation using visual aids is well solved by Miro. Hence, it is not considered as an unmet need in the roadmap stage.

Creating Product Requirements: PMs will use JIRA only if it is mandated by engineering. PMs prefer Docs over JIRA for writing requirements. 

No single convenient tool that allows for the comfort of writing & rigour of tracking:  Google docs is far more convenient than JIRA for creating product requirements since it provides maximum convenience. On JIRA, a PM writing a PRD with 8-9 user stories will have to click on their UI at least 30 times which is a lot more hassle than just doing core writing work on Docs. However, JIRA is used by engineering for consumption of requirements and translation to JIRA from Docs will always have mistakes in copy paste or clarity gaps.

Prototyping & Metric Tracking: Both problems have solutions such as Figma or Snowflake which are heavily focused on the designer or the analyst. There does not exist a solution which enables PMs to do easy prototyping & metric tracking on the vast majority of simple requests.


Prioritising Feature Requests:
For a senior PM, the true value of the product is when the tool is able to help drive alignment on the product vision & expected product launches faster. Hence, AI-1 on action item tracking will drive our core success metrics the best. 
2 helps PMs align engg & all other stakeholders to consume the roadmap & can also be used to align upward leadership. Hence, this will also be critical to PMF.
3 is focused towards easy consumption of requirements which is a convenience feature.
Similarly for 4, PMs usually have UX & Analytics resources to help & hence can be managed. Hence, 4 is also a convenience feature with much higher effort required since it requires capability building on UX & Querying which are very different products than the rest of the above.
Hence PMF: 1 & 2. (1 & 2) > 3 > 4 in order of execution.

Solution Space: PMF Features

Convenient Creation & Tracking of AIs for Roadmap & PRD Closure: Users should be able to create action items/plan conveniently for usecases such as a) roadmap creation & b) PRD closure.  
Be capable of importing action item/execution plan from Google sheets or have a Google sheet like UX that can be converted into a task tracker with capabilities such as ETAs, owners & priorities. 
Have reminders & escalation mechanisms for high priority action items by reaching out to owners & creating threads on email & slack. Users can choose to enable reminders or have them set to default on threads & sub-threads. This can be further enhanced by integrating with the org matrix (HR tech tools) as a fast follower & escalating to owners on high priority action tasks.
Have intelligent nudging on the number of priorities (too many priorities is a bad sign). 

Convenient Consumption of Roadmap for Engg Estimation & Tradeoffs for Upward Leaders:
Convenient creation of high-level reqs: One-stop shop where PMs can write a high level initiative list with breakdown of user stories. This can either be a google sheets type editor or can import from an existing sheet. 
Automated Engg Consumption & Easy Effort Estimation: This tool should allow integration with JIRA for engineering consumption & automate creation of epics & stories. Effort estimates can be added on JIRA which can sync back to this tool. Also engineers should be able to add high-level effort estimates directly on the tool.
Easy creation of tradeoff views: PMs should also be able to create custom metrics using this tool & create a roadmap view of resourcing vs impact using the inputs mentioned.

Would end the case here in limited time while focusing on roadmap & alignment of action items. 


If we have more time, will focus on the other engagement features such as:

Convenience Features for Repeat Usage:
Convenient JIRA consumption of Requirements: This tool should also allow PMs to write requirements in a simple text editor format. The text editor can be pre-populated with a template using the high-level stories mentioned above. When users write requirements on this editor, it should automate addition of details in JIRA tickets.
Convenient Consumption of UX in PRD: No need to copy paste designs on Figma, integration with product stories that allow UX designers to create UX under user story folders & auto-populate on PRD. Prototyping on the text editor as a fast follower as a one-stop shop for engg to consume.
Quick Prototyping: Enable quick drag & drop prototyping on standard UX templates 
Quick Querying: Convenient natural language based querying of simple metrics using templates.
Company_Normalized: Navi (fintech startup in India founded by ex Flipkart)

What was the interview question?: You join a wellness platform as a new PM. The team you lead has been tasked with building a product to help ppl track their nutrition habits and trends. How would you go about building that?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Assumed North America and food logging / tracking. Mission: differentiate from competitors by making a lasting impact on people's lives. Hence habits need to be created at a younger age. 
Segments: young adults (18-24 yr old) x need to deepen their cooking skills and education around food
Hence my product should be:
- lasting in time
- evolve with phases of life
- not be a one-time app

Pb I chose to focus on (listed 5)
- I don't know how to cook hence going to the easiest prepped meal first
- I don't know when I need to log my food what quantities I've eaten (and weighing through scale adds incredible friction to process)

Solutions:
- Blue Apron x Instacart
Get recipes delivered to you and shopping list items already pre-selected for you in-app (through partners like Instacart or their own shopping inventory) and have that list items' nutrients logged in your app

Universal hand-measurement system
- Based the product not on classic measurement systems (kg, lb) but on hand gestures (ex: palm of hand = x lb, fist = y, etc), that are universal, transportable (when going out), a proxy good enough and useful to be learned at a younger age.

What was the interview question?: You are a PM for Google Maps.  Design a parking solution

A key reliability metric that we measure is completed trips / requested trips (C/R). While our C/R looks fairly healthy in general, we’ve noticed that C/R is materially worse on trips that were 50+ miles. We want to understand why & what we can do to improve reliability in these long-distance trips.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Problems: what are some user needs & considerations for why long-distance trips are less reliable?
Marketplace dynamics: what are the supply / demand & pricing / cost issues of addressing this issue?
Magical UX: how do we build a magical experience for both drivers & riders? What’s the MVP and longer term vision?
Experimentation: what does success look like for Uber? How will we know we’re improving things as we launch?

What was the interview question?: What are the metrics to measure Bad Ads? How will you measure and optimize the systems to build systems to test, training data, control, user behavior, advertising behavior. You have a team of designers, engineers, infrastructure engineers, advertisers, PMs etc.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Asked what do they mean by Bad Ads; 
Defined metrics around ads and their success, extrapolated how the measure of Bad ads will be defined and calculated.
Defined error rates and tests to measure efficacy of ads.
Summarized with NSM, pseudo metrics, approach to test and balance bad ads and concluded with how its important to keep tracking bad ads, while keeping some ads in the system to measure overall efficiency of the system.

If you're a PM for Instagram shop, how would you improve it?
Create a home automation remote control and tell me about it.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
I asked a lot of clarifying questions to hone in on what features should be included, what the price point should be, who the customer is, what constraints the customer might have, etc. 
We decided that it was a home automation remote control for senior citizens. I made sure to talk through my thought process (Seniors may have limited mobility or use of their hands, a voice feature might be a great idea... on the other hand, we need data to show price points for that, and might need to piggy back on technology already created for the voice control). 

Overall, it was a really fun question to dive into. Have fun in your interview. It's all about showing them who you are as a creative and logical thinker. :) Good luck!

What was the interview question?: You are getting pressure from leadership to deliver a product  that you think is incomplete and want to hold back the launch. How do you proceed?
Question Type (e.g. Product, Strategy): GCA (General Cognitive Ability), RRK (Role Related Knowledge)
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Have an open convo with leadership on why there's so much pressure to launch on the set date. See if there's any wiggle room after they have the info of the incompleteness. 
Meet with the eng team to see if we can re-allocate resources or find resources elsewhere to help. 
Size the impact for both scenarios and share with everyone involved.

What was the interview question?:
You are the PM of a product that has a number of intersecting features of an end to end user journey. The UX is disjointed and it needs a complete overhaul. How do you determine the strategy for sequencing the work? 
Follow ups: How would you measure how big the problem is, how would you measure success?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Work with UX on end to end vision and share to get alignment. 
Chunk out into smaller bits of work.
Measure impact of each chunk and prioritize based on largest problems first.
Measure CSAT, usage dropoff, performance and churn.

What was the interview question?: You are leading a project involving a number of your peers (PMs), you get feedback from an engineering manager that one of the PMs on the project don't have clear requirements. How do you proceed?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
First ask if they spoke directly with the PM yet. 
Then assess the situation to see if  there's a reason that PM is moving faster, if they need more time and might need to stop working on other things in order to focus on this project. 
Also see if they are a newer member and aren't used to the level of detail this team expects.

What was the interview question?: The data of a dashboard you own is displaying data that is old and out of date. An engineer on your team knows about this and says they need to retry the job to update the data. An exec reaches out and says the data is out of date. How do you respond?
Comments (e.g. your approach):
First I find out what data the exec was looking for and get them the info manually for the time being and let them know you are working on a fix. 
Then I ask the engineer how long they knew that it was broken, and if we were alerted about it sooner. I shouldn't have found out from the exec that it was broken, we should have monitoring in place that lets us know. Then size the root cause of the issue to bring in the work to fix against existing priorities.

Comments (e.g. your approach):
The interviewer broke down the question at the start by asking me to choose a product and explain why. I chose Zoom among Google Meet, WebX, Whatsapp video conferencing, Facetime. 

The interviewer asked me what Product Goal would I set for my team to help them understand what they should build. I set the goal of engagement however the interviewer went back and forth in this section for 15 mins. (Not the time I expected to spend here)

Did not go as well. The breaking down of the question and the clues the interviewer gave me threw me off. Spending so much time on goal setting led to just leaving 5 mins to finish metrics cause the interviewer mentioned he needs 10 mins in the end for tradeoff. 

Then quickly jumped to Users, User Value, Metrics, NSM. 

Tradeoff question : You are a PM for the product and deciding what feature to build in next 6 months between 'Image background blur' vs 'In video chat' . What would you decide to build?

Comments (e.g. your approach): Use the Product Sense approach: clarify the question (this is a new product, should be connected to Meta's product portfolio), product understand (align to mission, talk about potential value for Meta Ecosystem, from users, creators, brands and Meta), set your goal both short term (adoption) and long term (engagement), talk about user segments, call out your segmentation method, prioritize your segments using volume (TAM) and existing relationship to product, talk about painpoints, prioritize painports using severity, existing solutions (underserving segment?), impact to your goal, solutions: vanilla (via Facebook App) and hot (AI implementation or something more tech savvy).

What was the interview question?: How would you improve the post-booking experience on Google Flights?

Daily Active users reduced over past week:
6-7%

noticed in service booking
mainly home related, personal services.

which activity are we referring to?
complete bookings.

timeframe in which it happened?
last week only its observed.

which platform?
no website, mobile app.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Interview Framework:

Internal factors: 
start with your product

Any changes by other teams

Any changes within the company

External factors: 
Political changes, global landscape changes, competitor changes





is our data about decline accurate? any issues with tool identified?
yes
any historical patterns similar.
maybe in past, not in recent times.
question regarding users, old or new
no pattern
demographic decline?
no
any new changes released?
yes, updated, cosmetic changes(ux)
Analyze user journey in depth.
login, browse the service he's looking for, goes through prices and timeslots.
what is observed is everything on these steps remain consistent, discovery is happening properly.
detail page once selected service, any changes here?
yes, providing more details and background on service providers.
What is the additional information added apart from the basic information like price and user ratings?
Yes, review section added, also custom services that particular person would provide added(Long text answers).
Since these are most recent changes, lets focus on these, any changes in booking button position?
Yes
conclusion1: It can be one of the scenario, can we check with analytics team if scrolling down to booking button at the bottom is causing changes?




External factors check":
Any specific changes done on checkout page?
No
Any specific competitor/stakeholders/marketing changes anything?
yes, but not in last one week.
Since, pandemic time, any effects from external sources like people's reluctance to services etc?
Not people but some societies adhered strict guidelines on outsiders entering.
conclusion2: users will look for someone local rather than outsider.
Any media narratives about such services transferring news which blew out of proportion?
No
User check: had it fallen across all services like this or limited to only our service?
Return question: how would look at play store to validate this?
Check number of installs, uninstalls and recent reviews.








Now summarize :STAR(Situation, Task, Action, Result)

Problem(Drop in DA user)
Went with a narrow down inside to outside approach.
Gone through the recent changes done in the last week in ui improvement, change in booking button.
To address this, launch it to our internal users.take feedback from them
Check if any specific issues raised on playstore reviews and our internal users
in external factors,
guidelines by societies, out of control but from our point, we can do stronger marketing that we are covid free.

2) What is a weakness you’re currently working on? How did you identify it, and what steps are you taking to improve?

3) Describe a time you had a conflict with a colleague. How did you handle the situation, and what was the outcome?

4) Tell me about a time you took ownership of a project that wasn’t directly your responsibility. What motivated you to take it on, and what impact did it have?
Design a product for fundraising
If you are PM at Disney, design a product for theme parks.
Define success for Netflix Podcast
You're the PM for LinkedIn Jobs: How would you increase the number of people hired through LinkedIn Jobs?
You are a PM at Meta for Workchat app that is part of Workplace products. Why should Meta invest in this product? Define goals and success metrics.

Measure success for Meta AI chatbot in Instagram DM. Imagine, it is designed to enhance user interaction by providing automated responses, user enquiries and fun experiences. Why would you build this product? What would you set as a goal, and how would you measure your product's success towards that goal?
Comments (e.g. your approach): Lots of follow-ups: Can you speak to competitors and why meta should do this? Break the broad goals into user outcomes, which goal you would prioritize and why? How could the NSM be gamed? Why track both weekly and monthly active users? Tradeoff: how much history would you give the AI to user for context and why?

PM for Zoom. Why does the product exist, what are success metrics and goals you would set.
PM at Uber/Lyft. Design a product for senior citizens.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Interviewer nudged a lot. When I went into the ecosystem players of (riders, drivers, friends & family of riders, & Uber) he said explicitly I think its clear we want to build for riders without any acknowledgement that you can build for drivers OR for friends/family of riders.

Didn't like my segmentation of tech resistant, basic tech, & high tech users. Asked for other ways to segment outside of my original segmentation. Asked for more user problems outside of the 3 problems I gave as well.  

For solutions, didn't care that I broke features out into MVP vs Future State along with risks and risk mitigations for MVP. 

Seems like interviewer had a preconceived notion of where the interview should have gone instead of being open to the fact that there are no right answers.

What was the interview question?:

If you were the PM, so you are the product owner, and you are setting out to design a roadmap for V2, how would you go about doing it.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
Initially focused on Defining the Problem Space ( User + Market), User Research and Segmentation. 
List out what are the Key Jobs to be Done, Pain Points identified today.  
Move into defining Goals and Success Metrics for Users and for the Company. 
Then moved into Strategic Pillars of the Roadmap. 
Finally Prioritize and Discuss Trade-offs.

You are a PM for Notification Service.  Why should Meta build it, what is its goal and how do you measure its success.
Comments (e.g. your approach):
- Product Motivation:
    - What problem it solves:
        - Getting to know of interesting or important messages/actions taken
        - Allows the users to take action

    - Why Meta:
        - Lots of users
        - Platform that is used by many
        - Allows the users to be more engaged on its platform

    - What would it be in for Meta:
        - Engagement → Retention → Revenue

    - Mission statement:  Empower people/business to be notified of the information that is important/interesting to them.
        - Engagement

- Ecosystem + Value + Action + Metrics
    - Users/Businesses/Advertiser
        - Value: Being notified of the information. Stay current. Stay engaged (with end user)
            - Metrics:
                - Number of notifications received per D/W/M
                - Number …
    - Meta
        - Value: Measure the health of the service. Gauge the business and operational metrics.
- Mission statement:  Empower people/business to be notified of the information that is important/interesting to them.
- Metrics:
    - NSM
        - Option 1: Total Number of Notifications Managed per day
            - Positive: Show the scale
            - Negative: Does not show from the user point of view.
        - Option 2: Number of users engaged with the service per day
            - Positive: Shows the level of engagement
            - Negative: Does not show the scale
- Option 3: Number of active users engaged with the service per day
    - Positive: Shows the level of engagement and is more aligned with the mission.
    - Negative: does not indicate the happiness factor.
        - Option 4: Number of notifications that result in an engagement between two or more parties per day.
        - Option 5: Ration of users engaged in notification per day
            - Number of users interacting with notifications/Total number of active users of FB
            - 15/50 = 30%
        - Option 6: Percentage revenue attributed to notifications service
            - Total time spent in the platform based on notification interactions
            - Unit measure of revenue minutes

My approach was to clarify the assumption:
- What are the different types of customer complaints?

- What's the impact associated with each of these complaints?
- What's the dollar value at stake?
- What do they mean by reducing customer complaints?
- Is it bringing down the amount that would be unlogged if we reduce the complaints by 30%?
- Is there a specific complaint that I should prioritize?
